title: Lack of rate limiting on get.uber.com leads to enumeration of promotion codes and estimation of a lower bound on the number of Uber drivers

summaries.content: Through enumerating Uber invite codes one could come up with a lower bound on the number of Uber drivers. This was only a lower bound because some people changed their invite codes so enumerating the ~60 million default invite codes would not find theirs.
summaries.content_html: Through enumerating Uber invite codes one could come up with a lower bound on the number of Uber drivers. This was only a lower bound because some people changed their invite codes so enumerating the ~60 million default invite codes would not find theirs.

activities.message:
I will note that I have not fully tested this (don't want to accidentally go too far in terms of testing it). So far I have not run into any rate limiting on this endpoint, but it is possible that rate limiting may kick in later on. With your permission, I would be more than happy to run a full test of this vulnerability. 

Thanks,
David Dworken

activities.message:
Hey @ddworken,

Thanks for the report!

As I'm sure you can imagine, we've had a deluge of reports since going public with our bug bounty program yesterday - please be patient with us through this process. My plan is to validate this issue tomorrow morning and I'll update this thread ASAP.

Cheers,
Rob

This particular issue has a low severity and as such might take a little more time to get fixed.

Cheers,

activities.message:
hey @ddworken - what real life throughput were you able to achieve when running this? Or rather if you were to exploit this what do you think you could reasonably achieve (spin up some aws boxes, etc)

We found that we do indeed have 5 character codes here but they go all the way up to 12 characters in different scenarios.

activities.message:
In a similar report ([#125488](https://hackerone.com/reports/125488)), I was able to write a multi-threaded scanner that could do 2400 requests per second from a compute engine instance on GCE with a gigabit connection. At this point  we can do some unit analysis:

380,204,032 requests * 1 second per 2400 requests * 1 minute per 60 seconds * 1 hour per 60 minutes * 1 day per 24 hours = 1.835 days (1 day and 20 hours)

Overall I would say it is pretty easy to brute force, with the caveat that I think someone at Uber may notice the additional load on the page and implement throttling. 

Thanks,
David Dworken
activities.markdown_message:

Overall I would say it is pretty easy to brute force, with the caveat that I think someone at Uber may notice the additional load on the page and implement throttling.

Thanks,

activities.message: Hi @ddworken, this seems to be resolved. Can you verify?
activities.markdown_message: Hi @ddworken, this seems to be resolved. Can you verify?

activities.message:
Yup, looks like this has been resolved since the default invite codes now start with ```<firstName><firstLetterOfLastName>``` (followed by 7 random digits). 

Thanks,
David Dworken

additional_data.new_title: Lack of rate limiting on get.uber.com leads to enumeration of promotion codes and estimation of a lower bound on the number of Uber drivers
additional_data.old_title: Enumeration of Invite Codes Allows for Estimating Number of Uber Riders

activities.message: Hey @ddworken, I updated the report title on this one to be a little more descriptive of the main issue that was awarded in this report as we've had a bit of confusion in some other reports that reference this one. Thanks again for the report!
activities.markdown_message: Hey @ddworken, I updated the report title on this one to be a little more descriptive of the main issue that was awarded in this report as we've had a bit of confusion in some other reports that reference this one. Thanks again for the report!

vulnerability_information_html:
Invite codes are 5 alphanumeric (lower case) characters. This means there are 36 (26 + 10) possible options for each space in the invite code. In total this means there are 36^5 or 60,466,176 possible invite codes. Through enumerating through all possible invite codes, one can find the total number of Uber accounts and the first name associated with each of the uber accounts.

When loading https://get.uber.com/invite/[Invite Code], one will see one of two possible messages. If you see only Create your account and get moving in minutes. then there is no account associated with that invite code. If you see Sign up now to claim your free gift from [First Name] ($15 off first ride)*., then there is an account associated with that invite code.

For an example of each of the possible responses, see the two below links:

https://get.uber.com/invite/v1m8a

https://get.uber.com/invite/v1m8u

A simple (but inefficient) way of exploiting this is with a simple python program like this (I have not tested the below code): 

import requests

characters = '0123456789abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz' # 

def isAccount(code):
    if "free gift from" in requests.get("https://get.uber.com/invite/"+code).content:
        return True
    return False

numAccounts = 0

for firstChar in characters:
    for secondChar in characters: 
        for thirdChar in characters:
            for fourthChar in characters:
                for fifthChar in characters:
                    if isAccount(firstChar + secondChar + thirdChar + fourthChar + fifthChar):
                        numAccounts += 1

Furthermore, one does not need to actually test all 60,466,176 invite codes. Since the invite codes are distributed randomly, one can simply test a subset of that and extrapolate. For example, if I test 1 million invite codes and find 3% are valid, then I know that approximately 3% of the 60,466,176 possible invite codes are valid (only an estimate).

Thanks,
David Dworken
